intro: Vouacapoua cujabensis, commonly known as the cujá-brazil nut tree, is a member of the Malvaceae family and is native to the Amazon rainforest. It is a large evergreen tree that can grow up to 30 meters tall, characterized by its smooth, dark bark and broad, palmately lobed leaves. The plant produces yellowish flowers with five petals, followed by woody capsules that contain edible seeds, commonly referred to as Brazil nuts. Its fruiting bodies are highly valued for their seeds, which are rich in nutrients and oils. The tree plays an important ecological role in its habitat, providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
